description:
Computes the absolute value of a real number `x`, which is the "unsigned" portion of x and often denoted as *|x|*.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed absolute value.

links.title: Absolute value explained by Wolfram MathWorld

summary: Adds a new dimension with the name in `dimension`.
description: Adds a new dimension with the name in `dimension`.

Computes a temporal aggregation based on an array of date/datetime ranges. Will be projected to the labels. Length of labels and groups needs to be the same. All data along the dimensions will be passed through the reducer. Calendar hierarchies such as year, month, week etc. will be transformed from the clients into groups.
Aggregates zonal data/statistics for one or multiple GeoJSON polygons. For focal aggregation see `apply`. Number of valid/invalid pixels get returned together with the calculated values.

summary: Are all of the values true?
description:
Checks if **all** of the values are true. Evaluates each expression from the first to the last element and stops once the outcome is unambiguous.

By default all no-data values are ignored so that the process returns `true` if all other values are true and otherwise returns `false`.

Setting the `ignore_nodata` flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is a valid logical object. If a component is `null`, the result will be `null` if the outcome is ambiguous. See the following truth table:

```
      || null  | false | true
----- || ----- | ----- | -----
null  || null  | false | null
false || false | false | false
true  || null  | false | true
```

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not and ignores them by default.

returns.description: Boolean result of the logical expressions.

description: Applies an n-ary process to a raster data cube. `dimensions` are the dimensions over which to iterate, if not set all dimensions are iterated over.

summary: Applies a local/unary process to a raster data cube.
description: Applies a local non-reducer to a raster data cube. Focal calculations can be made by setting the kernel. For zonal apply see `aggregate_zonal`. Returns a new raster data cube. The kernel has to be as many dimensions as the datacube has dimensions.

Computes the arcus cosine of `x`. The arcus cosine is the inverse function of the cosine so that *arccos(cos(x)) = x*.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed angle in radians.

links.title: Inverse cosine explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the inverse hyperbolic cosine of `x`. It is the inverse function of the hyperbolic cosine so that *arcosh(cosh(x)) = x*.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed angle in radians.

links.title: Inverse hyperbolic cosine explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the arcus sine of `x`. The arcus sine is the inverse function of the sine so that *arcsin(sin(x)) = x*.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed angle in radians.

links.title: Inverse sine explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the arcus tangent of `x`. The arcus tangent is the inverse function of the tangent so that *arctan(tan(x)) = x*.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed angle in radians.

links.title: Inverse tangent explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the arcus tangent of two numbers `x` and `y`. It is similar to calculating the arcus tangent of *y / x*, except that the signs of both arguments are used to determine the quadrant of the result.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated if any of the arguments is `null`.

y.description: A number to be used as dividend.

x.description: A number to be used as divisor.

returns.description: The computed angle in radians.

links.title: Two-argument inverse tangent explained by Wikipedia

description:
Checks whether the list (also known as *array*) specified for `data` contains the value specified in `element`.

**Remarks:**
* Data types MUST be checked strictly, for example a string with the content *1* is not equal to the number *1*.
* An integer *1* is equal to a floating point number *1.0* as `integer` is a sub-type of `number`. Still, this process may return unexpectedly `false` when comparing floating point numbers due to floating point inaccuracy in machine-based computation.
* Temporal strings are treated as normal strings and MUST NOT be interpreted.

data.description: List in which to find a value in.

returns.description: Returns `true` if the list contains the value, false` otherwise.

summary: Get an element from an array
description: Returns the element at the specified index from the array.

index.description: The zero-based index of the element to retrieve.

return_nodata.description: By default this process throws an `IndexOutOfBounds` exception if the index is invalid. If you want to return `null` instead, set this flag to `true`.

returns.description: The value of the requested element.

IndexOutOfBounds.message: The array has no element with the specified index.

description:
Computes the inverse hyperbolic sine of `x`. It is the inverse function of the hyperbolic sine so that *arsinh(sinh(x)) = x*.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed angle in radians.

links.title: Inverse hyperbolic sine explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the inverse hyperbolic tangent of `x`. It is the inverse function of the hyperbolic tangent so that *artanh(tanh(x)) = x*.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed angle in radians.

links.title: Inverse hyperbolic tangent explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Checks whether `x` is greater than or equal to `min` and lower than or equal to `max` or to put it in simpler words checks whether `x` is between the lower bound `min` and the upper bound `max`. Therefore, this process is an alias for `and([gte(x, min), lte(x, max)])` and all definitions from these processes apply here as well.

Lower and upper bounds are not allowed to be swapped. So `min` MUST be lower than or equal to `max` or otherwise the process always returns `false`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if `x` is between the specified bounds, otherwise `false`.

examples.description: Swapped bounds (min is greather than max) MUST always return `false`.

description:
The least integer greater than or equal to the number `x`.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The number rounded up.

links.title: Ceiling explained by Wolfram MathWorld

summary: Clips values between minimum and maximum values.
description: Clips the raster data cube values between specified min and max values. All values larger than maximal value will have the maximal value, all values lower than minimal value will have the minimal value, alias for `replace(replace(cube, gt(data, max), max), lt(data, min), min)`

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed cosine of `x`.

links.title: Cosine explained by Wolfram MathWorld

Computes the hyperbolic cosine of `x`.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

description: Number of valid elements (see is_valid).

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

summary: Create an empty raster data cube
description: Creates a new raster data cube without dimensions.

Finds cumulative maxima of an array of numbers. Every computed element is equal to the bigger one between current element and previous element. The returned array and the input array have always the same length.

By default, no-data values are skipped, but stay in the result. Setting the `ignore_nodata` flag to `true` makes that once a no-data value / `null` is reached all following elements are set to `null` in the result.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is set for all the following elements.

returns.description: An array with the computed cumulative maxima.

description:
Finds cumulative minima of an array of numbers. Every computed element is equal to the smaller one between current element and previous element. The returned array and the input array have always the same length.

By default, no-data values are skipped, but stay in the result. Setting the `ignore_nodata` flag to `true` makes that once a no-data value / `null` is reached all following elements are set to `null` in the result.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is set for all the following elements.

returns.description: An array with the computed cumulative minima.

description:
Computes cumulative products of an array of numbers. Every computed element is equal to the product of current and all previous values. The returned array and the input array have always the same length.

By default, no-data values are skipped, but stay in the result. Setting the `ignore_nodata` flag to `true` makes that once a no-data value / `null` is reached all following elements are set to `null` in the result.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is set for all the following elements.

returns.description: An array with the computed cumulative products.

description:
Computes cumulative sums of an array of numbers. Every computed element is equal to the sum of current and all previous values. The returned array and the input array have always the same length.

By default, no-data values are skipped, but stay in the result. Setting the `ignore_nodata` flag to `true` makes that once a no-data value / `null` is reached all following elements are set to `null` in the result.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is set for all the following elements.

returns.description: An array with the computed cumulative sums.

x divided all other elements

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

description: The real number *e* is a mathematical constant that is the base of the natural logarithm such that *ln(e) = 1*. The numerical value is approximately *2.71828*.

returns.description: Returns the numerical value of Euler's number.

links.title: Mathematical constant e explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Compares whether `x` is strictly equal to `y`.

**Remarks:**
* Data types MUST be checked strictly, for example a string with the content *1* is not equal to the number *1*. Nevertheless, an integer *1* is equal to a floating point number *1.0* as `integer` is a sub-type of `number`.
* If any of the operands is `null`, the return value is `null`.
* Strings are expected to be encoded in UTF-8 by default.
* Temporal strings MUST be compared differently than other strings and MUST NOT be compared based on their string representation due to different possible representations. For example, the UTC time zone representation `Z` has the same meaning as `+00:00`.

delta.description:
Only applicable for comparing two numbers. If this optional parameter is set to a positive non-zero number the equality of two numbers is checked against a delta value. This is especially useful to circumvent problems with floating point inaccuracy in machine-based computation.

This option is basically an alias for the following computation: `lte(abs(minus([x, y]), delta)`

case_sensitive.description: Only applicable for comparing two strings. Case sensitive comparison can be disabled by setting this parameter to `false`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if `x` is equal to `y`, `null` if any of the operands is `null`, otherwise `false`.

links.title: Information about the supported temporal formats.

description:
Exponential function to the base *e* raised to the power of `p`. This process is an alias for *e^p^* / `power(e(), p)`.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed value for *e* raised to the power of `p`.

links.title: Exponential function explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description: Export process that is compatible to GDAL/OGR formats and options. Passes through the data cube, so that further intermediate results can be exported and further calculations can be processes.
Two element array containing the minimum and the maximum values of `data`. Basically an alias for `min` and `max`, but potentially faster than calling both separately.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

**Remarks:**

* Temporal strings can *not* be compared based on their string representation due to the timezone / time-offset representations.
* Comparing strings is currently not supported, but is planned to be added in the future.

* Temporal strings can *not* be compared based on their string representation due to the timezone / time-offset representations.

description:
Returns the value of the `accept` parameter if the expression is `true` or the value of the `reject` parameter if the expression is `false`. This works similar to an if-then-else construct.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

accept.description: A value that is returned if the boolean expression is `true`. Defaults to `true`.

reject.description: A value that is returned if the boolean expression is `false`. Defaults to `false`.

returns.description: Returns either the `accept` argument or `reject` argument depending on the given boolean expression.

This process is *not* an alias for the `floor` process as defined by some mathematicians, see the examples for negative numbers in both processes for differences.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: Integer part of the number.

description: Checks whether the specified value `x` is not a number (often abbreviated as `NaN`). The definition of `NaN` follows the [IEEE Standard 754](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4610935). All non-numeric data types MUST also return `false`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if the data is not a number, otherwise `false`

links.title: IEEE Standard 754-2008 for Floating-Point Arithmetic

summary: Value is not a no-data value
description: Checks whether the specified data is a missing data, i.e. equals to one of the no-data values / `null`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if the data is a no-data value, otherwise `false`

description:
Checks whether the specified value `x` is valid. A value is considered valid if it is 
1. not a no-data value (`null`) and 
2. a finite number (only if `x` is a number). The definition of finite and infinite numbers follows the [IEEE Standard 754](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4610935).

returns.description: Returns `true` if the data is valid, otherwise `false`

links.title: IEEE Standard 754-2008 for Floating-Point Arithmetic

description: Last element of nums.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

description:
Performs a linear transformation between the input and output range.

The underlying formula is: `((x - inputMin) / (inputMax - inputMin)) * (outputMax - outputMin) + outputMin`.

Potential use case include
* scaling values to the range of the RGB color model (0 - 255) or
* calculating percentages (0 - 100).

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

inputMin.description: Minimum value the input can obtain.

inputMax.description: Maximum value the input can obtain.

outputMin.description: Minimum value of the desired output range.

outputMax.description: Maximum value of the desired output range.

returns.description: The transformed number.

links.title: Information about the supported temporal formats.

description:
The natural logarithm is the logarithm to the base *e* of the number `x`. This process is an alias for the *log* process with the base set to *e*: `log(x, e())`. The natural logarithm is the inverse function of taking *e* to the power x.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

x.description: A number to compute the natural logarithm for.

returns.description: The computed natural logarithm.

links.title: Natural logarithm explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Logarithm to the base `base` of the number `x` is defined to be the inverse function of taking b to the power of x.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated if any of the arguments is `null`.

x.description: A number to compute the logarithm for.

returns.description: The computed logarithm.

links.title: Logarithm explained by Wolfram MathWorld

* Temporal strings can *not* be compared based on their string representation due to the timezone / time-offset representations.

description:
Remainder after division of `x` by `y`.

The result of a modulo operation has the sign of the divisor. The handling regarding the sign of the result [differs between programming languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modulo_operation) and needs careful consideration while implementing this process.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated if any of the arguments is `null`.

x.description: A number to be used as dividend.

y.description: A number to be used as divisor.

returns.description: The remainder after division.

links.title: Modulo explained by Wikipedia

description:
Computes the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). The NDVI is computed as *(nir - red) / (nir + red)*.

The `data` parameter expects a raster data cube with two bands that have the common names `red` and `nir` assigned. The process returns a raster data cube with two bands being replaced with a new band that holds the computed values. For ease of use the newly created band should be named `ndvi`.

This process is very similar to the `normalized_difference` process, but determines the bands automatically based on the common name (`red`/`nir`) specified in the metadata.

data.description: A raster data cube with two bands that have the common names `red` and `nir` assigned.

returns.description: A raster data cube with two bands being replaced with a new band (preferably named `ndvi`) that holds the computed values.

links.title: NDVI explained by Wikipedia
NDVI explained by NASA

description:
Compares whether `x` is *not* strictly equal to `y`. This process is an alias for: `not(eq(val1, val2))`.

**Remarks:**
* Data types MUST be checked strictly, for example a string with the content *1* is not equal to the number *1*. Nevertheless, an integer *1* is equal to a floating point number *1.0* as `integer` is a sub-type of `number`.
* If any of the operands is `null`, the return value is `null`.
* Strings are expected to be encoded in UTF-8 by default.
* Temporal strings MUST be compared differently than other strings and MUST NOT be compared based on their string representation due to different possible representations. For example, the UTC time zone representation `Z` has the same meaning as `+00:00`.

delta.description:
Only applicable for comparing two numbers. If this optional parameter is set to a positive non-zero number the non-equality of two numbers is checked against a delta value. This is especially useful to circumvent problems with floating point inaccuracy in machine-based computation.

This option is basically an alias for the following computation: `gt(abs(minus([x, y]), delta)`

case_sensitive.description: Only applicable for comparing two strings. Case sensitive comparison can be disabled by setting this parameter to `false`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if `x` is *not* equal to `y`, `null` if any of the operands is `null`, otherwise `false`.

links.title: Information about the supported temporal formats.

description:
Computes the normalized difference for two bands. The normalized difference is computed as *(band1 - band2) / (band1 + band2)*.

Each of the parameters expects a raster data cube with exactly one band. The process returns a raster data cube with exactly one band that holds the computed values. For ease of use the newly created band should be named `normalized_difference`.

This process could be used for a number of remote sensing indices such as:

* [NDVI](https://eos.com/ndvi/)
* [NDWI](https://eos.com/ndwi/)
* [NDSI](https://eos.com/ndsi/)

Please note that some back-ends may have native processes such as the `NDVI`process available for convenience.

band1.description: A raster data cube with exactly one band to be used as first band.

band2.description: A raster data cube with exactly one band to be used as second band.

returns.description: A raster data cube with exactly one band (preferably named `normalized_difference`) that holds the computed values.

links.title: NDVI explained by EOS
NDWI explained by EOS
NDSI explained by EOS

description:
Inverts a single boolean so that `true` gets `false` and `false` gets `true`.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: Inverted boolean value.

summary: Is at least one value true?
description:
Checks if **at least one** of the values is true. Evaluates each expression from the first to the last element and stops once the outcome is unambiguous.

By default all no-data values are ignored so that the process returns `true` if at least one of the other values is true and otherwise returns `false`.

Setting the `ignore_nodata` flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is a valid logical object. If a component is `null`, the result will be `null` if the outcome is ambiguous. See the following truth table:

```
      || null | false | true
----- || ---- | ----- | ----
null  || null | null  | true
false || null | false | true
true  || true | true  | true
```

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not and ignores them by default.

returns.description: Boolean result of the logical expressions.

description: Computes a permutation which allows rearranging the data into ascending or descending order. Ties will be left in their original ordering.
Outputs the data to the client, who needs to be subscribed to the topic `openeo.jobs.output`.
The real number Pi () is a mathematical constant that is the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter. The numerical value is approximately *3.14159*.

returns.description: Returns the numerical value of Pi.

links.title: Mathematical constant Pi explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the exponentiation for the base `base` raised to the power of `p`.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated if any of the arguments is `null`.

returns.description: The computed value for `base` raised to the power of `p`.

links.title: Power explained by Wolfram MathWorld

Calculates quantiles for each specified `quantiles` between 0 and 1.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

description: Rearranges an array based on a permutation.

summary: reduce dimensions - lower dimensionality, same resolution.
description: reduce dimensions - lower dimensionality, same resolution.
Resample spatial dimension
If dimension is not set, the data cube is expected to have only one temporal dimension.

Rounds a real number `x` to specified precision `p`.

If the fractional part of `x` is halfway between two integers, one of which is even and the other odd, then the even number is returned.
This behavior follows [IEEE Standard 754](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4610935). This kind of rounding is also called "rounding to nearest" or "banker's rounding". It minimizes rounding errors that result from consistently rounding a midpoint value in a single direction.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

p.description: A positive number specifies the number of digits after the decimal point to round to. A negative number means rounding to a power of ten, so for example *-2* rounds to the nearest hundred. Defaults to *0*.

returns.description: The rounded number.

links.title: Absolute value explained by Wolfram MathWorld

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

description:
The signum (also known as *sign*) of `x` is defined as:
* *1* if *x > 0*
* *0* if *x = 0*
* *-1* if *x < 0*

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed signum value of `x`.

links.title: Sign explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the sine of `x`.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed sine of `x`.

links.title: Sine explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the hyperbolic sine of `x`.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed hyperbolic sine of `x`.

links.title: Hyperbolic sine explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description: Sorts `data` into ascending (default) or descending order. Removes no-data values. Basically an alias to rearrange()

Computes the square root of a real number `x`. This process is an alias for `x` to the power of *0.5*: `power(x, 0.5)`.

A square root of x is a number a such that *a^2^ = x*. Therefore, the square root is the inverse function of a to the power of 2, but only for *a >= 0*.

The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed square root.

links.title: Square root explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description: sum of all elements

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

description:
Computes the tangent of `x`. The tangent is defined to be the sine of x divided by the cosine of x.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed tangent of `x`.

links.title: Tangent explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description:
Computes the hyperbolic tangent of `x`. The tangent is defined to be the hyperbolic sine of x divided by the hyperbolic cosine of x.

Works on radians only.
The no-data value `null` is passed through and therefore gets propagated.

returns.description: The computed hyperbolic tangent of `x`.

links.title: Hyperbolic tangent explained by Wolfram MathWorld

description: Checks whether the text (also known as *string*) specified for `data` contains the text specified for `pattern` at the very beginning. Both are expected to be encoded in UTF-8 by default. Regular expressions are not supported.

data.description: Text in which to find something at the beginning.

pattern.description: Text to find at the beginning of `data`.

case_sensitive.description: Case sensitive comparison can be disabled by setting this parameter to `false`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if `data` begins with `pattern`, false` otherwise.

description: Checks whether the text (also known as *string*) specified for `data` contains the text specified for `pattern`. Both are expected to be encoded in UTF-8 by default. Regular expressions are not supported.

data.description: Text in which to find something in.

case_sensitive.description: Case sensitive comparison can be disabled by setting this parameter to `false`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if `data` contains the `pattern`, false` otherwise.

description: Checks whether the text (also known as *string*) specified for `data` contains the text specified for `pattern` at the very end. Both are expected to be encoded in UTF-8 by default. Regular expressions are not supported.

data.description: Text in which to find something at the end.

pattern.description: Text to find at the end of `data`.

case_sensitive.description: Case sensitive comparison can be disabled by setting this parameter to `false`.

returns.description: Returns `true` if `data` ends with `pattern`, false` otherwise.

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not. Ignores them by default. Setting this flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is returned if any value is such a value.

description: Weighted raster filter

Checks if **exactly one** of the values is true. Evaluates each expression from the first to the last element and stops once the outcome is unambiguous.

By default all no-data values are ignored so that the process returns `true` if exactly one of the other values is true and otherwise returns `false`.

Setting the `ignore_nodata` flag to `false` considers no-data values so that `null` is a valid logical object. If a component is `null`, the result will be `null` if the outcome is ambiguous. See the following truth table:

```
      || null | false | true
----- || ---- | ----- | -----
null  || null | null  | null
false || null | false | true
true  || null | true  | false
```

ignore_nodata.description: Indicates whether no-data values are ignored or not and ignores them by default.

returns.description: Boolean result of the logical expressions.
